types.name: AccessToken
types.description: An access token that grants to the holder the privileges of the user who created it.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The unique ID for the access token.

fields.name: subject
fields.description: The user whose privileges the access token grants.

fields.name: scopes
fields.description: The scopes that define the allowed set of operations that can be performed using this access token.

fields.name: note
fields.description: A user-supplied descriptive note for the access token.

fields.name: creator
fields.description:
The user who created the access token. This is either the subject user (if the access token
was created by the same user) or a site admin (who can create access tokens for any user).

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The date when the access token was created.

fields.name: lastUsedAt
fields.description: The date when the access token was last used to authenticate a request.

fields.name: totalCount

The total count of access tokens in the connection. This total count may be larger than the number of nodes
in this object when the result is paginated.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

SAML). The provider information in this type is visible to all viewers and does not contain any secret values.

fields.name: serviceID

fields.name: clientID

fields.name: displayName

fields.name: isBuiltin
fields.description: Whether this auth provider is the builtin username-password auth provider.

fields.name: authenticationURL
fields.description: A URL that, when visited, initiates the authentication process for this auth provider.

fields.name: nodes

fields.name: totalCount

The total count of authentication providers in the connection. This total count may be larger than the number of nodes
in this object when the result is paginated.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

fields.name: username

fields.name: displayName

fields.name: avatarURL

fields.name: inOrg

types.name: BatchChange
types.description: A batch change is a set of related changes to apply to code across one or more repositories.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The unique ID for the batch change.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: The namespace where this batch change is defined.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the batch change.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description (as Markdown).

fields.name: state
fields.description: The state of the batch change.

fields.name: specCreator
fields.description: The user that created the initial spec. In an org, this will be different from the namespace, or null if the user was deleted.
fields.deprecationReason: Unused. This always incorrectly returned the current batch specs creator, not the intial one. This field is deprecated and will be removed in a future release.

fields.name: initialApplier
fields.description:
The user who created the batch change initially by applying the spec for the first time, or null if the user was deleted.

This is an alias of BatchChange.creator.
fields.deprecationReason: Use creator instead. This field is deprecated and will be removed in a future release.

fields.name: creator
fields.description: The user who created the batch change, or null if the user was deleted.

fields.name: lastApplier
fields.description:
The user who last updated the batch change by applying a spec to this batch change.
If the batch change hasn't been updated, the lastApplier is the initialApplier, or null if the user was deleted.

fields.name: viewerCanAdminister
fields.description: Whether the current user can edit or delete this batch change.

fields.name: url
fields.description: The URL to this batch change.

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The date and time when the batch change was created.

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description:
The date and time when the batch change was updated. That can be by applying a spec, or by an internal process.
For reading the time the batch change spec was changed last, see lastAppliedAt.

fields.name: lastAppliedAt
fields.description:
The date and time when the batch change was last updated with a new spec. Null, if a batch spec has never been
applied yet.

fields.name: closedAt
fields.description: The date and time when the batch change was closed. If set, applying a spec for this batch change will fail with an error.

fields.name: changesetsStats
fields.description: Stats on all the changesets that are tracked in this batch change.

fields.name: changesets
fields.description: The changesets in this batch change that already exist on the code host.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

args.name: reconcilerState
args.description: Only include changesets with any of the given reconciler states.

args.name: publicationState
args.description: Only include changesets with the given publication state.

args.name: externalState
args.description: Only include changesets with the given external state.

args.name: state
args.description: Only include changesets with the given state.

args.name: onlyClosable
args.description:
Query only changesets that are either open or draft. This is used on the close page to list changesets that remain open.
When set, passing state is not allowed.

args.name: reviewState
args.description: Only include changesets with the given review state.

args.name: checkState
args.description: Only include changesets with the given check state.

args.name: onlyPublishedByThisBatchChange
args.description: Only return changesets that have been published by this batch change. Imported changesets will be omitted.

args.name: search
args.description: Search for changesets matching this query. Queries may include quoted substrings to match phrases, and words may be preceded by - to negate them.

args.name: onlyArchived
args.description: Only return changesets that are archived in this batch change.

args.name: repo
args.description: Only include changesets belonging to the given repository.

fields.name: changesetCountsOverTime
fields.description:
The changeset counts over time, in 1-day intervals backwards from the point in time given in
the "to" parameter.

args.name: from
args.description: Only include changeset counts up to this point in time (inclusive). Defaults to BatchChange.createdAt.

args.name: to
args.description:
Only include changeset counts up to this point in time (inclusive). Defaults to the
current time.

args.name: includeArchived
args.description: Include archived changesets in the calculation.

fields.name: diffStat
fields.description: The diff stat for all the changesets in the batch change.

fields.name: currentSpec
fields.description:
The last batch spec applied to this batch change, or an "empty" spec if the batch
change has never had a spec applied.

fields.name: bulkOperations
fields.description: The bulk operations that have been run over this batch change.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n entries from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

args.name: createdAfter
args.description: Filter by createdAt value.

fields.name: batchSpecs
fields.description:
The batch specs that have been running on this batch change.

Site-admins can see all of them, non admins can only see batch specs that they
created.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n entries from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

fields.name: nodes

fields.name: totalCount

fields.name: pageInfo

types.name: BatchChangeDescription
types.description: A BatchChangeDescription describes a batch change.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name as parsed from the input.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description as parsed from the input.

types.name: BatchChangeState
types.description: The state of the batch change.

types.name: BatchChangesCodeHost
types.description: A code host usable with batch changes. This service is accessible by the user it belongs to.

fields.name: externalServiceKind
fields.description: The kind of external service.

fields.name: externalServiceURL
fields.description: The URL of the external service.

fields.name: credential
fields.description: The configured credential, if any.

fields.name: requiresSSH
fields.description:
If true, some of the repositories on this code host require
an SSH key to be configured.

fields.name: hasWebhooks
fields.description: If true, the code host has webhooks configured.

types.name: BatchChangesCodeHostConnection
types.description:
A connection of all code hosts usable with batch changes and accessible by the user
this is requested on.

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of code hosts.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description: The total number of configured external services in the connection.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: BatchChangesCredential
types.description: A user token configured for batch changes use on the specified code host.

fields.name: id
fields.description: A globally unique identifier.

fields.name: externalServiceKind
fields.description: The kind of external service.

fields.name: externalServiceURL
fields.description: The URL of the external service.

fields.name: sshPublicKey
fields.description:
The public key to use on the external service for SSH keypair authentication.
Not set if the credential doesn't support SSH access.

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The date and time this token has been created at.

fields.name: isSiteCredential
fields.description: Whether the configured credential is a site credential, that is available globally.

types.name: BatchSpec
types.description:
A batch spec is an immutable description of the desired state of a batch change. To create a
batch spec, use the createBatchSpec mutation.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
The unique ID for a batch spec.

The ID is unguessable (i.e., long and randomly generated, not sequential).
Consider a batch change to fix a security vulnerability: the batch change author may prefer
to prepare the batch change, including the description in private so that the window
between revealing the problem and merging the fixes is as short as possible.

fields.name: autoApplyEnabled
fields.description:
Future: Flag that calls applyBatchChange automatically when this execution completes.
Useful for integrations with code monitoring etc.

TODO: Not implemented yet.

fields.name: state
fields.description:
The current execution state of the batch spec. For manually created ones (src-cli workflow),
this will always be COMPLETED. This is an accumulated state over all the associated
workspaces for convenience.

fields.name: originalInput
fields.description: The original YAML or JSON input that was used to create this batch spec.

fields.name: parsedInput
fields.description:
The parsed JSON value of the original input. If the original input was YAML, the YAML is
converted to the equivalent JSON.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The BatchChangeDescription that describes this batch change.

fields.name: applyPreview
fields.description:
Generates a preview showing the operations that would be performed if the
batch spec was applied. This preview is not a guarantee, since the state
of the changesets can change between the time the preview is generated and
when the batch spec is applied.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n entries from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

args.name: search
args.description: Search for changesets matching this query. Queries may include quoted substrings to match phrases, and words may be preceded by - to negate them.

args.name: currentState
args.description: Search for changesets that are currently in this state.

args.name: action
args.description: Search for changesets that will have the given action performed.

args.name: publicationStates
args.description:
If set, it will be assumed that these changeset specs will have their
UI publication states set to the given values when the batch spec is
applied.

An error will be returned if the same changeset spec ID is included
more than once in the array, or if a changeset spec ID returned within
this page has a publication state set in its spec.

Note: Unlike createBatchChange(), this query will not validate that all
changeset specs in the array correspond to valid changeset specs within
the batch spec, as they may not all be loaded on the current page.

fields.name: changesetSpecs
fields.description: The specs for changesets associated with this batch spec.

fields.name: creator
fields.description:
The user who created this batch spec. Their permissions will be honored when
executing the batch spec. Null, if the user has been deleted.

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description:
The time when the batch spec was created at. At this time, it is also added to
the queue for execution, if created from raw.

fields.name: startedAt
fields.description:
The time when the execution started. Null, if the execution hasn't started
yet, or if the batch spec was created in COMPLETED state.

fields.name: finishedAt
fields.description:
The time when the execution finished. Null, if the execution hasn't finished
yet, or if the batch spec was created in COMPLETED state.
This value is the time of when the batch spec has been sealed.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: The namespace (either a user or organization) of the batch spec.

fields.name: expiresAt
fields.description:
The date, if any, when this batch spec expires and is automatically purged. A batch spec
never expires if it has been applied.

fields.name: applyURL
fields.description:
The URL of a web page that allows applying this batch spec and
displays a preview of which changesets will be created by applying it.
Null, if the execution has not finished yet.

fields.name: viewerCanAdminister
fields.description: When true, the viewing user can apply this spec.

fields.name: diffStat
fields.description:
The diff stat for all the changeset specs in the batch spec. Null if state is
not COMPLETED.

fields.name: appliesToBatchChange
fields.description:
The batch change this spec will update when applied. If it's null, the
batch change doesn't yet exist.

fields.name: supersedingBatchSpec
fields.description:
The newest version of this batch spec, as identified by its namespace
and name. If this is the newest version, this field will be null.

fields.name: viewerBatchChangesCodeHosts
fields.description:
The code host connections required for applying this spec. Includes the credentials of the current user.
Only returns useful information if state is COMPLETED.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n code hosts from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

args.name: onlyWithoutCredential
args.description: Only returns the code hosts for which the viewer doesn't have credentials.

args.name: onlyWithoutWebhooks
args.description: Only returns code hosts that don't have webhooks configured.

fields.name: workspaceResolution
fields.description:
A wrapper for the workspace resolution on this batch spec. Contains access to
all workspaces that have been resolved, as well as insight into the state of
the resolution.
Null, if the batch spec was created in COMPLETED state.

fields.name: importingChangesets
fields.description:
The set of changeset specs for importing changesets, as determined from the
raw spec.
Null, if not created through createBatchSpecFromRaw.

fields.name: failureMessage
fields.description:
Set when something about this batch spec is not right. For example, the input spec
is invalid, or if ValidateChangesetSpecs throws an error when the last job completes.

fields.name: allowIgnored
fields.description:
If true, repos with a .batchignore file will still be included in the
execution.

Null, if not created through createBatchSpecFromRaw.

fields.name: allowUnsupported
fields.description:
If true, repos on unsupported codehosts will be included in the execution.
These cannot be published.

Null, if not created through createBatchSpecFromRaw.

fields.name: viewerCanRetry
fields.description:
If true, viewer can retry the batch spec execution by calling
retryBatchSpecExecution.

types.name: BatchSpecConnection

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of batch specs.

types.name: BatchSpecState
types.description: The possible states of a batch spec.

enumValues.name: PENDING
enumValues.description: The spec is not yet enqueued for processing.

enumValues.name: PROCESSING
enumValues.description: This spec is being processed.

enumValues.name: FAILED
enumValues.description: This spec failed to be processed.

enumValues.name: COMPLETED
enumValues.description: This spec was processed successfully.

enumValues.name: QUEUED
enumValues.description: This spec is queued to be processed.

enumValues.name: CANCELING
enumValues.description: The execution is being canceled.

enumValues.name: CANCELED
enumValues.description: The execution has been canceled.

types.name: BatchSpecWorkspace
types.description: A workspace in Batch Changes to run in.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The unique ID for the workspace.

fields.name: repository
fields.description: The repository to run over.

fields.name: batchSpec
fields.description: Used for reverse querying.

fields.name: branch
fields.description: The branch to run over.

fields.name: path
fields.description: The path to run in.

fields.name: onlyFetchWorkspace
fields.description: If true, only the files within the workspace will be fetched.

fields.name: ignored
fields.description:
If true, this workspace has been skipped, because some rule forced this.
For now, the only one is a .batchignore file existing in the repository.

fields.name: unsupported
fields.description:
If true, this workspace has been skipped, because the code host on which
the repository is hosted is not supported.

fields.name: cachedResultFound
fields.description:
Whether we found a task cache result.

TODO: Not implemented yet.

fields.name: stages
fields.description:
Executor stages of running in this workspace. Null, if the execution hasn't
started yet.

fields.name: steps
fields.description: List of steps that will need to run over this workspace.

fields.name: step
fields.description: Get a specific step by its index. Index is 1-based.

fields.name: searchResultPaths
fields.description:
If this workspace was resolved based on a search, this is the list of paths
to files that have been included in the search results.

fields.name: queuedAt
fields.description: The time when the workspace was enqueued for processing. Null, if not yet enqueued.

fields.name: startedAt
fields.description: The time when the workspace started processing. Null, if not yet started.

fields.name: finishedAt
fields.description: The time when the workspace finished processing. Null, if not yet finished.

fields.name: failureMessage
fields.description: Optional failure message, set when the execution failed.

fields.name: state
fields.description: The current state the workspace is in.

fields.name: changesetSpecs
fields.description:
Populated, when the execution is finished. This is where you get the combined
diffs.

fields.name: placeInQueue
fields.description:
The rank of this execution in the queue. The value of this field is null if the
execution has started.

fields.name: diffStat
fields.description:
The diff stat over all created changeset specs. Null, if not yet finished or
failed.

fields.name: executor
fields.description:
The executor that picked up this job. Null, if the executor has been pruned
from the data set or if the job has not started yet.
Only available to site-admins.

types.name: BatchSpecWorkspaceResolutionState
types.description: State of the workspace resolution.

enumValues.name: QUEUED
enumValues.description: Not yet started resolving. Will be picked up by a worker eventually.

enumValues.name: PROCESSING
enumValues.description: Currently resolving workspaces.

enumValues.name: ERRORED
enumValues.description: An error occured while resolving workspaces. Will be retried eventually.

enumValues.name: FAILED
enumValues.description: A fatal error occured while resolving workspaces. No retries will be made.

enumValues.name: COMPLETED
enumValues.description: Resolving workspaces finished successfully.

types.name: BatchSpecWorkspaceStages
types.description:
Configuration and execution summary of a batch spec execution. This is mostly
meant for internal consumption, for the timeline view.

fields.name: setup
fields.description: Execution log entries related to setting up the workspace.

fields.name: srcExec
fields.description:
Execution log entry related to running src batch exec.
This field is null, if the step had not been executed.

fields.name: teardown
fields.description: Execution log entries related to tearing down the workspace.

types.name: BatchSpecWorkspaceState
types.description: The states a workspace can be in.

enumValues.name: SKIPPED
enumValues.description:
The workspace will not be enqueued for execution, because either the
workspace is unsupported/ignored or has 0 steps to execute.

enumValues.name: PENDING
enumValues.description: The workspace is not yet enqueued for execution.

enumValues.name: QUEUED
enumValues.description: Not yet started executing. Will be picked up by a worker eventually.

enumValues.name: PROCESSING
enumValues.description: Currently executing on the workspace.

enumValues.name: FAILED
enumValues.description: A fatal error occured while executing. No retries will be made.

enumValues.name: COMPLETED
enumValues.description: Execution finished successfully.

enumValues.name: CANCELING
enumValues.description: Execution is being canceled. This is an async process.

enumValues.name: CANCELED
enumValues.description: Execution has been canceled.

enumValues.description:
The changeset reconciler is currently computing the delta between the
If a delta exists, the reconciler tries to update the state of the

types.name: ChangesetSpec
types.description:
A changeset spec is an immutable description of the desired state of a changeset in a batch change. To
create a changeset spec, use the createChangesetSpec mutation.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
The unique ID for a changeset spec.

The ID is unguessable (i.e., long and randomly generated, not sequential). This is important
even though repository permissions also apply to viewers of changeset specs, because being
allowed to view a repository should not entitle a person to view all not-yet-published
changesets for that repository. Consider a batch change to fix a security vulnerability: the
batch change author may prefer to prepare all of the changesets in private so that the window
between revealing the problem and merging the fixes is as short as possible.

fields.name: type
fields.description: The type of changeset spec.

fields.name: expiresAt
fields.description:
The date, if any, when this changeset spec expires and is automatically purged. A changeset
spec never expires (and this field is null) if its batch spec has been applied.

A configuration policy that applies to a set of Git objects matching an associated
pattern. Each policy has optional data retention and auto-indexing schedule configuration
attached. A policy can be applied globally or on a per-repository basis.

fields.description: A pattern matching the name of the matching Git object.

fields.name: protected
fields.description: Protected policies may not be deleted (or created directly by users).

fields.name: retentionEnabled
fields.description: Whether or not this configuration policy affects data retention rules.

fields.name: retentionDurationHours
fields.description: The max age of data retained by this configuration policy.

fields.name: retainIntermediateCommits
fields.description:
If the matching Git object is a branch, setting this value to true will also
retain all data used to resolve queries for any commit on the matching branches.
Setting this value to false will only consider the tip of the branch.

fields.name: indexingEnabled
fields.description: Whether or not this configuration policy affects auto-indexing schedules.

fields.name: indexCommitMaxAgeHours
fields.description: The max age of commits indexed by this configuration policy.

fields.name: indexIntermediateCommits
fields.description:
If the matching Git object is a branch, setting this value to true will also
index all commits on the matching branches. Setting this value to false will
only consider the tip of the branch.

An optional revision, e.g. "pr/feature-1", "a9505a2947d3df53558e8c88ff8bcef390fc4e3e".
If omitted, we use the latest revision (HEAD).

inputFields.name: lineContext
inputFields.description: Number of lines to show before and after the matched symbol line.

inputFields.name: symbolName
inputFields.description: The symbol name.

inputFields.name: symbolContainerName
inputFields.description: Name of the symbol container.

inputFields.name: symbolKind
inputFields.description: The symbol kind.

types.name: CreateUserResult
types.description: The result for Mutation.createUser.

fields.name: user
fields.description: The new user.

fields.name: resetPasswordURL
fields.description:
The reset password URL that the new user must visit to sign into their account. If the builtin
username-password authentication provider is not enabled, this field's value is null.

types.name: DateTime
types.description:
An RFC 3339-encoded UTC date string, such as 1973-11-29T21:33:09Z. This value can be parsed into a
JavaScript Date using Date.parse. To produce this value from a JavaScript Date instance, use
Date#toISOString.

types.name: DefaultSettings
types.description:
The default settings for the Sourcegraph instance. This is hardcoded in
Sourcegraph, but may change from release to release.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The opaque GraphQL ID.

fields.name: latestSettings
fields.description: The latest default settings (this never changes).

fields.name: settingsURL
fields.description:
The URL to the default settings. This URL does not exist because you
cannot edit or directly view default settings.

fields.name: viewerCanAdminister
fields.description:
Whether the viewer can modify the subject's settings. Always false for
default settings.

fields.name: settingsCascade
fields.description:
The default settings, and the final merged settings.
All viewers can access this field.

fields.name: configurationCascade
fields.description: DEPRECATED
fields.deprecationReason: Use settingsCascade instead. This field is a deprecated alias for it and will be removed in a future release.

types.name: Diagnostic
types.description: Represents a diagnostic, such as a compiler error or warning.

fields.name: location
fields.description: The location at which the message applies.

fields.name: severity
fields.description: The diagnostic's severity.

fields.name: code
fields.description: The diagnostic's code as provided by the tool.

fields.name: source
fields.description:
A human-readable string describing the source of this
diagnostic, e.g. "typescript" or "super lint".

fields.name: message
fields.description: The diagnostic's message.

types.name: DiagnosticConnection
types.description: A list of diagnostics.

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of diagnostics.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description: The total count of diagnostics (which may be larger than nodes.length if the connection is paginated).

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: DiagnosticSeverity
types.description: Represents the severity level of a diagnostic.

types.name: Diff
types.description: A diff between two diffable Git objects.

fields.name: repository
fields.description: The diff's repository.

fields.name: range
fields.description: The revision range of the diff.

types.name: DiffHunkLineType
types.description: The type of content in a hunk line.

enumValues.name: ADDED
enumValues.description: Added line.

enumValues.name: UNCHANGED
enumValues.description: Unchanged line.

enumValues.name: DELETED
enumValues.description: Deleted line.

types.name: DiffStat
types.description: Statistics about a diff.

fields.name: added
fields.description: Number of additions.

fields.name: changed
fields.description: Number of changes.

fields.name: deleted
fields.description: Number of deletions.

types.name: Documentation
types.description: Documentation at some position in a file.

fields.name: pathID
fields.description:
The path ID of the documentation, which can be used to build a link to the documentation or
(after trimming the URL hash) passed to documentationPage or documentationPathInfo.

types.name: DocumentationPage
types.description: Describes a single page of documentation.

fields.name: tree
fields.description:
The tree of documentation nodes describing this page's hierarchy. It is a JSON value because
GraphQL has terrible support for recursive data structures: https://github.com/graphql/graphql-spec/issues/91

The exact structure of this value is documented here:
https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=repo:%5Egithub%5C.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph%24+type+DocumentationNode+struct&patternType=literal&case=yes

types.name: DocumentationSearchResult
types.description: A documentation search result.

fields.name: language
fields.description: The lowercase language name (go, java, etc.) OR, if unknown, the LSIF indexer name.

fields.name: repoName
fields.description: RepoName is the name of the repository containing this search key.

fields.name: searchKey
fields.description:
The search key generated by the indexer, e.g. mux.Router.ServeHTTP. It is language-specific,
and likely unique within a repository (but not always.) See protocol/documentation.go:Documentation.SearchKey

fields.name: pathID
fields.description:
The fully qualified documentation page path ID, e.g. including "#section". See the documentationPage
type for what this is.

fields.name: label
fields.description: Markdown label string, e.g. a one-line function signature. See protocol/documentation.go:Documentation

fields.name: detail
fields.description: Markdown detail string (e.g. the full function signature and its docs). See protocol/documentation.go:Documentation

fields.name: tags
fields.description: Tags for the documentation node. See protocol/documentation.go:Documentation

types.name: DocumentationSearchResults
types.description: Search results over documentation.

fields.name: results
fields.description: The results.

types.name: DotcomMutation
types.description:
Mutations that are only used on Sourcegraph.com.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

fields.name: setUserBilling
fields.description:
Set or unset a user's associated billing information.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may perform this mutation.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

args.name: user
args.description: The user to update.

args.name: billingCustomerID
args.description:
The billing customer ID (on the billing system) to associate this user with. If null, the association is
removed (i.e., the user is unlinked from the billing customer record).

fields.name: createProductSubscription
fields.description:
Creates new product subscription for an account.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may perform this mutation.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

args.name: accountID
args.description: The ID of the user (i.e., customer) to whom this product subscription is assigned.

fields.name: setProductSubscriptionBilling
fields.description:
Set or unset a product subscription's associated billing system subscription.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may perform this mutation.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

args.name: id
args.description: The product subscription to update.

args.name: billingSubscriptionID
args.description:
The billing subscription ID (on the billing system) to associate this product subscription with. If null,
the association is removed (i.e., the subscription is unlinked from billing).

fields.name: generateProductLicenseForSubscription
fields.description:
Generates and signs a new product license and associates it with an existing product subscription. The
product license key is signed with Sourcegraph.com's private key and is verifiable with the corresponding
public key.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may perform this mutation.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

args.name: productSubscriptionID
args.description: The product subscription to associate with the license.

args.name: license
args.description: The license to generate.

fields.name: createPaidProductSubscription
fields.description:
Creates a new product subscription and bills the associated payment method.
Only Sourcegraph.com authenticated users may perform this mutation.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

args.name: accountID
args.description:
The ID of the user (i.e., customer) to whom the product subscription is assigned.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may perform this mutation for an accountID != the user ID of the
authenticated user.

args.name: productSubscription
args.description: The details of the product subscription.

args.name: paymentToken
args.description:
The token that represents the payment method used to purchase this product subscription,
or null if no payment is required.

fields.name: updatePaidProductSubscription
fields.description:
Updates a new product subscription and credits or debits the associated payment method.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins and the subscription's account owner may perform this
mutation.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

args.name: subscriptionID
args.description: The subscription to update.

args.name: update
args.description:
The updated details of the product subscription. All fields of the input type must be set
(i.e., it does not support passing a null value to mean "do not update this field's
value").

args.name: paymentToken
args.description:
The token that represents the payment method used to pay for (or receive credit for) this
product subscription update, or null if no payment is required.

fields.name: archiveProductSubscription
fields.description:
Archives an existing product subscription.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may perform this mutation.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

types.name: DotcomQuery
types.description:
Mutations that are only used on Sourcegraph.com.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

fields.name: productSubscription
fields.description:
The product subscription with the given UUID. An error is returned if no such product
subscription exists.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins and the account owners of the product subscription may
perform this query.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

fields.name: productSubscriptions
fields.description:
A list of product subscriptions.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n product subscriptions from the list.

args.name: account
args.description:
Returns only product subscriptions for the given account.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may perform this query with account == null.

args.name: query
args.description: Returns product subscriptions from users with usernames or email addresses that match the query.

fields.name: previewProductSubscriptionInvoice
fields.description:
The invoice that would be generated for a new or updated subscription. This is used to show
users a preview of the credits, debits, and other billing information before creating or
updating a subscription.
Performing this query does not mutate any data or cause any billing changes to be made.

args.name: account
args.description: The customer account (user) for whom this preview invoice will be generated, or null if there is none.

args.name: subscriptionToUpdate
args.description:
If non-null, preview the invoice for an update to the existing product subscription. The
product subscription's billing customer must match the account parameter. If null, preview
the invoice for a new subscription.

args.name: productSubscription
args.description:
The parameters for the product subscription to preview. All fields of the input type must
be set (i.e., it does not support passing a null value to mean "do not update this field's
value" when updating an existing subscription).

fields.name: productLicenses
fields.description:
A list of product licenses.
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may perform this query.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n product subscriptions from the list.

args.name: licenseKeySubstring
args.description: Returns only product subscriptions whose license key contains this substring.

args.name: productSubscriptionID
args.description: Returns only product licenses associated with the given subscription

fields.name: productPlans
fields.description: A list of product pricing plans for Sourcegraph.

types.name: EmptyResponse
types.description: Represents a null return value.

fields.name: alwaysNil
fields.description: A dummy null value.

types.name: Error
types.description:
This type is not returned by any resolver, but serves to document what an error
response will look like.

fields.name: message
fields.description: A string giving more context about the error that ocurred.

fields.name: path
extensions
fields.description: Optional additional context on the error.

types.name: ErrorExtensions
types.description:
Optional additional context on an error returned from a resolver.
It may also contain more properties, which aren't strictly typed here.

fields.name: code
fields.description:
An error code, which can be asserted on.
Possible error codes are communicated in the doc string of the field.

types.name: EvaluatedFeatureFlag
types.description:
An evaluated feature flag is any feature flag (static or random) that has been evaluated to
a concrete value for a given viewer.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the feature flag

fields.name: value
fields.description: The concrete evaluated value of the feature flag

types.name: Event
types.description: A description of a user event.

inputFields.name: event
inputFields.description: The name of the event.

inputFields.name: userCookieID
inputFields.description: The randomly generated unique user ID stored in a browser cookie.

inputFields.name: firstSourceURL
inputFields.description: The first sourcegraph URL visited by the user, stored in a browser cookie.

inputFields.name: lastSourceURL
inputFields.description: The last sourcegraph URL visited by the user, stored in a browser cookie.

inputFields.name: url
inputFields.description: The URL when the event was logged.

inputFields.name: source
inputFields.description: The source of the event.

inputFields.name: cohortID
inputFields.description:
An optional cohort ID to identify the user as part of a specific A/B test.
The cohort ID is expected to be a date in the form YYYY-MM-DD

inputFields.name: referrer
inputFields.description:
An optional referrer parameter for the user's current session.
Only captured and stored on Sourcegraph Cloud.

inputFields.name: argument
inputFields.description: The additional argument information.

inputFields.name: publicArgument
inputFields.description:
Public argument information. PRIVACY: Do NOT include any potentially private information in this field.
These properties get sent to our analytics tools for Cloud, so must not include private information,
such as search queries or repository names.

inputFields.name: deviceID
inputFields.description: Device ID used for Amplitude analytics. Used on Sourcegraph Cloud only.

inputFields.name: eventID
inputFields.description:
Event ID used to deduplicate events that occur simultaneously in Amplitude analytics.
See https://developers.amplitude.com/docs/http-api-v2#optional-keys. Used on Sourcegraph Cloud only.

inputFields.name: insertID
inputFields.description:
Insert ID used to deduplicate events that re-occur in the event of retries or
backfills in Amplitude analytics. See https://developers.amplitude.com/docs/http-api-v2#optional-keys.
Used on Sourcegraph Cloud only.

types.name: EventLog
types.description: A single user event that has been logged.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the event.

fields.name: user
fields.description: The user who executed the event, if one exists.

fields.name: anonymousUserID
fields.description: The randomly generated unique user ID stored in a browser cookie.

fields.name: url
fields.description: The URL when the event was logged.

fields.name: source
fields.description: The source of the event.

fields.name: argument
fields.description: The additional argument information.

fields.name: version
fields.description: The Sourcegraph version when the event was logged.

fields.name: timestamp
fields.description: The timestamp when the event was logged.

types.name: EventLogsConnection
types.description: A list of event logs.

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of event logs.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description:
The total count of event logs in the connection. This total count may be larger than the number of nodes
in this object when the result is paginated.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: EventSource
types.description: The product sources where events can come from.

types.name: EventStatus
types.description: Supported status of monitor events.

types.name: ExecutionLogEntry
types.description: A description of a command run inside the executor to during processing of the parent record.

fields.name: key
fields.description: An internal tag used to correlate this log entry with other records.

fields.name: command
fields.description: The arguments of the command run inside the executor.

fields.name: startTime
fields.description: The date when this command started.

fields.name: exitCode
fields.description: The exit code of the command. Null, if the command has not finished yet.

fields.name: out
fields.description: The combined stdout and stderr logs of the command.

fields.name: durationMilliseconds
fields.description: The duration in milliseconds of the command. Null, if the command has not finished yet.

types.name: Executor
types.description: An active executor compute instance.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The unique identifier of this executor.

fields.name: hostname
fields.description: The hostname of the executor instance.

fields.name: queueName
fields.description: The queue name that the executor polls for work.

fields.name: active
fields.description: Active is true, if a heartbeat from the executor has been received at most three heartbeat intervals ago.

fields.name: os
fields.description: The operating system running the executor.

fields.name: architecture
fields.description: The machine architure running the executor.

fields.name: dockerVersion
fields.description: The version of Git used by the executor.

fields.name: executorVersion
fields.description: The version of the executor.

fields.name: gitVersion
fields.description: The version of Docker used by the executor.

fields.name: igniteVersion
fields.description: The version of Ignite used by the executor.

fields.name: srcCliVersion
fields.description: The version of src-cli used by the executor.

fields.name: firstSeenAt
fields.description: The first time the executor sent a heartbeat to the Sourcegraph instance.

fields.name: lastSeenAt
fields.description: The last time the executor sent a heartbeat to the Sourcegraph instance.

types.name: ExecutorConnection
types.description: A list of active executors compute instances.

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of executors.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description: The total number of executors in this result set.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: ExistingChangesetReference
types.description:
A reference to a changeset that already exists on a code host (and was not created by the
batch change).

fields.name: baseRepository
fields.description: The repository that contains the existing changeset on the code host.

fields.name: externalID
fields.description:
The ID that uniquely identifies the existing changeset on the code host.

For GitHub and Bitbucket Server, this is the pull request number (as a string) in the
base repository. For example, "1234" for PR 1234.

types.name: ExtensionManifest
types.description: A description of the extension, how to run or access it, and when to activate it.

fields.name: raw
fields.description:
The raw JSON (or JSONC) contents of the manifest. This value may be large (because many
manifests contain README and icon data), and it is JSONC (not strict JSON), which means
it must be parsed with a JSON parser that supports trailing commas and comments. Consider
using jsonFields instead.

fields.name: jsonFields
fields.description:
The manifest as JSON (not JSONC, even if the raw manifest is JSONC) with only the
specified fields. This is useful for callers that only need certain fields and want
to avoid fetching a large amount of data (because many manifests contain README
and icon data).

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description specified in the manifest, if any.

fields.name: bundleURL
fields.description: The URL to the bundled JavaScript source code for the extension, if any.

types.name: ExtensionRegistry
types.description: An extension registry.

fields.name: extension
fields.description:
Find an extension by its extension ID (which is the concatenation of the publisher name, a slash ("/"), and the
extension name).
To find an extension by its GraphQL ID, use Query.node.

fields.name: extensions
fields.description: A list of extensions published in the extension registry.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n extensions from the list.

args.name: publisher
args.description: Returns only extensions from this publisher.

args.name: query
args.description:
Returns only extensions matching the query.
The following keywords are supported:
- category:"C" - include only extensions in the given category.
- tag:"T" - include only extensions in the given tag.
The following keywords are ignored by the server (so that the frontend can post-process the result set to
implement the keywords):
- installed - include only installed extensions.
- enabled - include only enabled extensions.
- disabled - include only disabled extensions.

args.name: local
args.description: Include extensions from the local registry.

args.name: remote
args.description: Include extensions from remote registries.

args.name: extensionIDs
args.description: Returns only extensions with the given IDs.

args.name: prioritizeExtensionIDs
args.description: Sorts the list of extension results such that the extensions with these IDs are first in the result set.

fields.name: publishers
fields.description: A list of publishers with at least 1 extension in the registry.

args.name: first
args.description: Return the first n publishers from the list.

fields.name: viewerPublishers
fields.description: A list of publishers that the viewer may publish extensions as.

fields.name: localExtensionIDPrefix
fields.description:
The extension ID prefix for extensions that are published in the local extension registry. This is the
hostname (and port, if non-default HTTP/HTTPS) of the Sourcegraph "externalURL" site configuration property.
It is null if extensions published on this Sourcegraph site do not have an extension ID prefix.
Examples: "sourcegraph.example.com/", "sourcegraph.example.com:1234/"

fields.name: featuredExtensions
fields.description: A list of featured extensions in the registry.

types.name: ExtensionRegistryCreateExtensionResult
types.description: The result of Mutation.extensionRegistry.createExtension.

fields.name: extension
fields.description: The newly created extension.

types.name: ExtensionRegistryMutation
types.description: Mutations for the extension registry.

fields.name: createExtension
fields.description: Create a new extension in the extension registry.

args.name: publisher
args.description: The ID of the extension's publisher (a user or organization).

args.name: name
args.description: The name of the extension.

fields.name: updateExtension
fields.description:
Update an extension in the extension registry.
Only authorized extension publishers may perform this mutation.

args.name: extension
args.description: The extension to update.

args.name: name
args.description: The new name for the extension, or null to leave unchanged.

fields.name: deleteExtension
fields.description:
Delete an extension from the extension registry.
Only authorized extension publishers may perform this mutation.

args.name: extension
args.description: The ID of the extension to delete.

fields.name: publishExtension
fields.description:
Publish an extension in the extension registry, creating it (if it doesn't yet exist) or updating it (if it
does).
This is a helper that wraps multiple other GraphQL mutations to expose a single API for publishing an
extension.

args.name: extensionID
args.description:
The extension ID of the extension to publish. If a host prefix (e.g., "sourcegraph.example.com/") is
needed and it is not included, it is automatically prepended.
Examples: "alice/myextension", "acmecorp/myextension"

args.name: manifest
args.description: The extension manifest (as JSON).

args.name: bundle
args.description: The bundled JavaScript source of the extension.

args.name: sourceMap
args.description:
The source map of the extension's JavaScript bundle, if any.
The JavaScript bundle's "//# sourceMappingURL=" directive, if any, is ignored. When the bundle is served,
the source map provided here is referenced instead.

args.name: force
args.description: Force publish even if there are warnings (such as invalid JSON warnings).

types.name: ExtensionRegistryPublishExtensionResult
types.description: The result of Mutation.extensionRegistry.publishExtension.

fields.name: extension
fields.description: The extension that was just published.

types.name: ExtensionRegistryUpdateExtensionResult
types.description: The result of Mutation.extensionRegistry.updateExtension.

fields.name: extension
fields.description: The newly updated extension.

types.name: ExternalAccount
types.description: An external account associated with a user.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The unique ID for the external account.

fields.name: user
fields.description: The user on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: serviceType
fields.description: The type of the external service where the external account resides.

fields.name: serviceID
fields.description: An identifier for the external service where the external account resides.

fields.name: clientID
fields.description:
An identifier for the client of the external service where the external account resides. This distinguishes
among multiple authentication providers that access the same service with different parameters.

fields.name: accountID
fields.description: An identifier for the external account (typically equal to or derived from the ID on the external service).

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The creation date of this external account on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: The last-updated date of this external account on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: refreshURL
fields.description: A URL that, when visited, re-initiates the authentication process.

fields.name: accountData
fields.description:
Provider-specific data about the external account.
Only site admins may query this field.

types.name: ExternalAccountConnection
types.description: A list of external accounts.

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of external accounts.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description:
The total count of external accounts in the connection. This total count may be larger than the number of nodes
in this object when the result is paginated.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: ExternalChangeset
types.description: A changeset on a code host (e.g., a pull request on GitHub).

fields.name: id
fields.description: The unique ID for the changeset.

fields.name: externalID
fields.description:
The external ID that uniquely identifies this ExternalChangeset on the
code host. For example, on GitHub this is the pull request number. This is only set once the changeset is published on the code host.

fields.name: repository
fields.description: The repository changed by this changeset.

fields.name: batchChanges
fields.description: The batch changes that contain this changeset.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n batch changes from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

args.name: state
args.description: Only return batch changes in this state. If `states` is also specified, it will take precedence over `state`.

args.name: states
args.description: Only return batch changes in any of these states. If `state` is also specified, `states` will take precedence over it.

args.name: viewerCanAdminister
args.description: Only include batch changes that the viewer can administer.

fields.name: events
fields.description: The events belonging to this changeset.

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The date and time when the changeset was created.

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: The date and time when the changeset was updated.

fields.name: nextSyncAt
fields.description: The date and time when the next changeset sync is scheduled, or null if none is scheduled or when the initial sync hasn't happened.

fields.name: scheduleEstimateAt
fields.description:
The time the changeset is expected to be enqueued at. This is an estimate, and may change depending on other code host and Batch Changes activity.

Null if the changeset is not currently scheduled.

fields.name: title
fields.description: The title of the changeset, or null if the data hasn't been synced from the code host yet.

fields.name: body
fields.description: The body of the changeset, or null if the data hasn't been synced from the code host yet.

fields.name: author
fields.description:
The author of the changeset, or null if the data hasn't been synced from the code host yet,
or the changeset has not yet been published.

fields.name: publicationState
fields.description: The publication state of the changeset.
fields.deprecationReason: Use state instead. This field is deprecated and will be removed in a future release.

fields.name: reconcilerState
fields.description: The reconciler state of the changeset.
fields.deprecationReason: Use state instead. This field is deprecated and will be removed in a future release.

fields.name: externalState
fields.description: The external state of the changeset, or null when not yet published to the code host.
fields.deprecationReason: Use state instead. This field is deprecated and will be removed in a future release.

fields.name: state
fields.description: The state of the changeset.

fields.name: labels
fields.description: The labels attached to the changeset on the code host.

fields.name: externalURL
fields.description: The external URL of the changeset on the code host. Not set when changeset state is UNPUBLISHED, externalState is DELETED, or the changeset's data hasn't been synced yet.

fields.name: forkNamespace
fields.description:
If the changeset was opened from a fork, this is the namespace of the fork
(which will generally correspond to a user or organisation name on the code
host).

fields.name: reviewState
fields.description: The review state of this changeset. This is only set once the changeset is published on the code host.

fields.name: diff
fields.description: The diff of this changeset, or null if the changeset is closed (without merging) or is already merged.

fields.name: diffStat
fields.description:
The diffstat of this changeset, or null if the changeset is closed
(without merging) or is already merged. This data is also available
indirectly through the diff field above, but if only the diffStat is
required, this field is cheaper to access.

fields.name: checkState
fields.description:
The state of the checks (e.g., for continuous integration) on this changeset, or null if no
checks have been configured.

fields.name: error

fields.name: invitableCollaborators

EXPERIMENTAL: Collaborators who can be invited to Sourcegraph. This typically comes from a few
repositories included by this external service, and is derived from commit history (because that
for example gives more accurate collaborator work email addresses than the contributors API which
often returns personal emails.

Importantly, this API works when repositories are not cloned on Sourcegraph yet so as to allow
inviting collaborators while repositories are cloning.

In general, this API should NOT be used once repositories are cloned on to Sourcegraph as it
reaches out to the code host directly which is wasteful if repositories are already cloned.

fields.name: documentationPage
fields.description:
Returns the documentation page corresponding to the given path ID, where the path ID "/"
refers to the current git blob and can be used to walk all documentation below this git blob.

Currently this method is only supported on the root git blob of a repository.

A pathID refers to all the structured documentation slugs emitted by the LSIF indexer joined together
with a slash, starting at the slug corresponding to this git blob filepath. A pathID and filepath may
sometimes look similar, but are not equal. Some examples include:

* A documentation page under filepath `internal/pkg/mux` with pathID `/Router/ServeHTTP/examples`.
* A documentation page under filepath `/` (repository root) with pathID `/internal/pkg/mux/Router/ServeHTTP/examples`

In other words, a path ID is said to be the path to the page, relative to the git blob
filepath.

The components of the pathID are chosen solely by the LSIF indexer, and may vary over time or
even dynamically based on e.g. project size. The same is true of pages, e.g. an LSIF indexer
may choose to create new pages if an API surface exceeds some threshold size.

fields.name: documentationPathInfo
fields.description:
Returns the documentation pth info corresponding to the given path ID, where the empty string "/"
refers to the current tree entry and can be used to walk all documentation below this tree entry.

Currently this method is only supported on the root tree entry of a repository.

See @documentationPage for information about what a pathID refers to.

This method is optimal for e.g. walking the entire documentation path structure of a repository,
whereas documentationPage would require you to fetch the content for all pages you walk (not true
of path info.)

If maxDepth is specified, pages will be recursively returned up to that depth. Default max depth
is one (immediate child pages only.)

If ignoreIndex is true, empty index pages (pages whose only purpose is to describe pages below
them) will not qualify as a page in relation to the maxDepth property: index pages will be
recursively followed and included until a page with actual content is found, and only then will
the depth be considered to increment. Default is false.

This returns a JSON value because GraphQL has terrible support for recursive data structures: https://github.com/graphql/graphql-spec/issues/91

The exact structure of the return value is documented here:
https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=repo:%5Egithub%5C.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph%24+type+DocumentationPathInfoResult+struct&patternType=literal&case=yes

types.name: GitBranchChangesetDescription
types.description:
A description of a changeset that represents the proposal to merge one branch into another.
This is used to describe a pull request (on GitHub and Bitbucket Server).

fields.name: baseRepository
fields.description: The repository that this changeset spec is proposing to change.

fields.name: baseRef
fields.description:
The full name of the Git ref in the base repository that this changeset is based on (and is
proposing to be merged into). This ref must exist on the base repository. For example,
"refs/heads/master" or "refs/heads/main".

fields.name: baseRev
fields.description:
The base revision this changeset is based on. It is the latest commit in
baseRef at the time when the changeset spec was created.
For example: "4095572721c6234cd72013fd49dff4fb48f0f8a4"

fields.name: headRepository
fields.description: The repository that contains the branch with this changeset's changes.
fields.deprecationReason: Unused. Sourcegraph does not populate a full repository when creating a changeset on a fork. Use VisibleChangesetSpec.fork or ExternalChangeset.forkNamespace instead.

fields.name: headRef
fields.description:
The full name of the Git ref that holds the changes proposed by this changeset. This ref will
be created or updated with the commits. For example, "refs/heads/fix-foo" (for
the Git branch "fix-foo").

fields.name: title
fields.description:
The title of the changeset on the code host.

On Bitbucket Server or GitHub this is the title of the pull request.

fields.name: body
fields.description:
The body of the changeset on the code host.

On Bitbucket Server or GitHub this is the body/description of the pull request.

fields.name: commits
fields.description:
The Git commits with the proposed changes. These commits are pushed to the head ref.

Only 1 commit is supported.

fields.name: diff
fields.description: The total diff of the changeset diff.

fields.name: diffStat
fields.description:
The diffstat of this changeset spec. This data is also available
indirectly through the diff field above, but if only the diffStat is
required, this field is cheaper to access.

fields.name: published
fields.description:
Whether or not the changeset described here should be created right after
applying the ChangesetSpec this description belongs to.

If this is false, the changeset will only be created on Sourcegraph and
can be previewed.

Another ChangesetSpec with the same description, but "published: true",
can later be applied to publish the changeset.

fields.name: documentationPage
fields.description:
Returns the documentation page corresponding to the given path ID, where the empty string "/"
refers to the current tree entry and can be used to walk all documentation below this tree entry.

Currently this method is only supported on the root tree entry of a repository.

A pathID refers to all the structured documentation slugs emitted by the LSIF indexer joined together
with a slash, starting at the slug corresponding to this tree entry filepath. A pathID and filepath may
sometimes look similar, but are not equal. Some examples include:

* A documentation page under filepath `internal/pkg/mux` with pathID `/Router/ServeHTTP/examples`.
* A documentation page under filepath `/` (repository root) with pathID `/internal/pkg/mux/Router/ServeHTTP/examples`

In other words, a path ID is said to be the path to the page, relative to the tree entry
filepath.

The components of the pathID are chosen solely by the LSIF indexer, and may vary over time or
even dynamically based on e.g. project size. The same is true of pages, e.g. an LSIF indexer
may choose to create new pages if an API surface exceeds some threshold size.

fields.name: documentationPathInfo
fields.description:
Returns the documentation pth info corresponding to the given path ID, where the empty string "/"
refers to the current tree entry and can be used to walk all documentation below this tree entry.

Currently this method is only supported on the root tree entry of a repository.

See @documentationPage for information about what a pathID refers to.

This method is optimal for e.g. walking the entire documentation path structure of a repository,
whereas documentationPage would require you to fetch the content for all pages you walk (not true
of path info.)

If maxDepth is specified, pages will be recursively returned up to that depth. Default max depth
is one (immediate child pages only.)

If ignoreIndex is true, empty index pages (pages whose only purpose is to describe pages below
them) will not qualify as a page in relation to the maxDepth property: index pages will be
recursively followed and included until a page with actual content is found, and only then will
the depth be considered to increment. Default is false.

This returns a JSON value because GraphQL has terrible support for recursive data structures: https://github.com/graphql/graphql-spec/issues/91

The exact structure of the return value is documented here:
https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=repo:%5Egithub%5C.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph%24+type+DocumentationPathInfoResult+struct&patternType=literal&case=yes

fields.description: A list of definitions of the symbol described by the given documentation path ID, if any.

fields.name: documentationReferences
fields.description: A list of references of the symbol under the given document position.

args.name: pathID
args.description: The documentation path ID, e.g. from the documentationPage return value.

args.description:

args.name: first

how many results to return per page.

types.name: HiddenChangesetSpec
types.description:
A changeset spec is an immutable description of the desired state of a changeset in a batch change. To
create a changeset spec, use the createChangesetSpec mutation.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
The unique ID for a changeset spec.

The ID is unguessable (i.e., long and randomly generated, not sequential). This is important
even though repository permissions also apply to viewers of changeset specs, because being
allowed to view a repository should not entitle a person to view all not-yet-published
changesets for that repository. Consider a batch change to fix a security vulnerability: the
batch change author may prefer to prepare all of the changesets in private so that the window
between revealing the problem and merging the fixes is as short as possible.

fields.name: type
fields.description: The type of changeset spec.

fields.name: expiresAt
fields.description:
The date, if any, when this changeset spec expires and is automatically purged. A changeset
spec never expires (and this field is null) if its batch spec has been applied.

fields.name: failed
fields.description:
The number of queries belonging to the series that are terminally failed. These have either been marked as non-retryable or exceeded
the max retry limit. This count only represents the queries that have yet to be pruned by the background maintenance workers.

fields.name: queued
fields.description:
The number of queries belonging to the series that are queued for processing.
This count only represents the queries that have yet to be pruned by the background maintenance workers.

types.name: InsightSeriesStatus
types.description: Status indicators for a specific series of insight data.

fields.name: totalPoints
fields.description:
The total number of points stored for this series, at the finest level
(e.g. per repository, or per-repository-per-language) Has no strict relation
to the data points shown in the web UI or returned by `points()`, because those
are aggregated and this number _can_ report some duplicates points which get
stored but removed at query time for the web UI.

Why its useful: an insight may look like "it is doing nothing" but in reality
this number will be increasing by e.g. several thousands of points rapidly.

fields.name: pendingJobs
fields.description:
The total number of jobs currently pending to add new data points for this series.

Each job may create multiple data points (e.g. a job may create one data point per
repo, or language, etc.) This number will go up and down over time until all work
is completed (discovering work takes almost as long as doing the work.)

Why its useful: signals "amount of work still to be done."

fields.name: completedJobs
fields.description:
The total number of jobs completed for this series. Note that since pendingJobs will
go up/down over time, you CANNOT divide these two numbers to get a percentage as it
would be nonsense ("it says 90% complete but has been like that for a really long
time!").

Does not include 'failedJobs'.

Why its useful: gives an indication of "how much work has been done?"

fields.name: failedJobs
fields.description:
The total number of jobs that were tried multiple times and outright failed. They will
not be retried again, and indicates the series has incomplete data.

Use ((failedJobs / completedJobs) * 100.0) to get an approximate percentage of how
much data the series data may be missing (e.g. ((30 / 150)*100.0) == 20% of the series
data is incomplete (rough approximation, not precise).

Why its useful: signals if there are problems, and how severe they are.

fields.name: backfillQueuedAt
fields.description:
The time that the insight series completed a full iteration and queued up records for processing. This can
effectively be used as a status that the insight is still processing if returned null.

enumValues.description: This upload is currently being transferred to Sourcegraph.

enumValues.description:

fields.name: url

fields.name: events

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n events from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

types.name: MonitoringAlert
types.description: A high-level monitoring alert, for details see https://docs.sourcegraph.com/admin/observability/metrics#high-level-alerting-metrics

fields.name: timestamp
fields.description: End time of this event, which describes the past 12h of recorded data.

fields.name: name

fields.name: serviceName
fields.description: Name of the service that fired the alert.

fields.name: owner
fields.description: Owner of the fired alert.

fields.name: average
fields.description:
Average percentage of time (between [0, 1]) that the event was firing over the 12h of recorded data. e.g.
1.0 if it was firing 100% of the time on average during that 12h window, 0.5 if it was firing 50% of the
time on average, etc.

types.name: MonitoringStatistics

fields.name: alerts
